print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in ABS but its perfectly fine printing in PLA if you can print stuff that is capable of push in m3 nuts. My CTC Dual is optimized for small strong ABS prints, hence why I didn't use the TEVO Little Monster, which is optimized for big models in PLA/PETG.

description.text:
Wanted to tidy up the cabling on the TEVO Little Monster, hiding all the modular connections in an easy to reach place, but didn't want to involve using flexible filaments. I re-sheathed all the cabling with the cable braid used from a generic PC mod kit. I moved the floating extruder to a full bowden style on the top, and this design takes advantage of that. I used a set of springs to float it perfectly over the extruder, which also helps reduce sharp angles to prevent breaking of certain brittle filaments. It also prevents the hard casing knocking the rods.

This has allowed my extruder set up to be incredibly lightweight thus reducing vibration related artifacting and higher possible print speeds. I also fitted a genuine e3d v6 volcano. A user on the facebook group for this printer (Sorry couldn't find your name), mentioned there are 2 unused M3 holes by the hole on the top plate perfectly placed so you can actually screw the extruder motor assembly directly to it via the holes original made for the belts to hang it as a floating extruder. I placed it here on 20mm M3 spaces to allow easier access to the lever on the extruder assembly.

Requires:
4 x M3 nuts
4 x M3 8mm or longer (Counter-sunk LMCO-Lid.stl, Socket Cap LMCO-Lid-Alt.stl)
Several small zip-ties

Optional: 4 x Relatively weak 25mm Cylindrical Spiral Extension springs
I went through my box of various springs and found this work quite well, I don't really have any documentation on the springs but they have to be relatively weak and be able to loop around the rods or screws. One is attached on each of the bottom screws to a rod to the side of it. Another is set across both rods and a further spring is put in the center of this to the top of the cable organizer casing to the bowden tube/cabling.

The base is zip-tied to the cables and the lid is attached with a slot for the bowden tube.

Printer:

CTC Dual (Bizer)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

5-10%

Notes:

I printed this in ABS but its perfectly fine printing in PLA if you can print stuff that is capable of push in m3 nuts. My CTC Dual is optimized for small strong ABS prints, hence why I didn't use the TEVO Little Monster, which is optimized for big models in PLA/PETG.

description.text:
I was looking for a case for my old 256mb Pi, but there wasn't anything that was exactly what I was looking for. So I decided to model my own case inspired by Cesear's https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:446921.

The base has a couple of raised areas to support the Pi and keep the board level so that the ports stay aligned with the case openings. The top of the case pins the board in place by clamping the USB ports and a clamp block over the SD card. The GPIO pins are accessible by clipping out the 4 small supports on the cover to remove the small rectangular cover.

The case is held together with 12mm M3 screws in the 4 angled feet, from underneath. It relies on the screws biting into the top layer.

Printer:

Anet A8 (i3 clone)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I found that a skirt helps stop the 4 feet from cooling faster than the large mass of the base and the additional surface area stops them curling up and lifting off the bed.
The case is made with quite close tolerances, so depending on the alignment of the parts, you may have to sand port openings a little for a perfect fit.
Fusion 360 after following a few YouTube tutorials. It seems overwhelming at first but well worth the effort and gets easier after a few tutorials.

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194717 - the original didn't include print supports (and I didn't include them in the slicer), and I wanted to be able to tweak angles. There's also scope to change thickness of the printed part and how broad those beams are that make up the whole thing

Customizable to set the thickness of the bracket, the angles for the supports and optionally include print supports

The included .stl is the defaults as I see them.

Updated: 22nd May

  • Added configuration of total length (default now at 130mm to give better clearance for a charge cable)
  • Set default for Supports to Off (Slic3r didn't bridge the perimter correctly, YMMV)
  • Made Support for the bridge at 1.5mm instead of 0.5 to try and give the slicer a fighting chance
  • Reduced the gap in the Joycon rail keyway (1.2mm was a bit on the loose side, but still gave an acceptable hold on initial print)

Printer:

Foldarap

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Initial print didn't bridge the way I had intended, so I have omitted it in favour of a support. If your slicer does a better job, then you can customize and enable the those support aids.

If you include the print supports, small blocks are added to the end of the keyway so your slicer should bridge between these two points, increasing the odds of a successful print. carefully trim these away with a small knife (scalpel etc) so you can use the brackets

LilyPad LEDs are easy to use for a project - they incorporate an internal resistor so you can hook them up directly to 3.3-5V. In addition, the LilyPad Arduino makes programming them easy - so you can easily develop an external program to turn them on & off. We created these holders so they would be easy to incorporate into any 3D project.
What you'll need to ue them:

  • LilyPad LEDs
  • A power supply
  • Wires or conductive thread
    If you want to program them, add a LilyPad Arduino - we recommend the AMX3dUino, because the processor is removable from the connection so it's easy to reprogram!

These are designed to be used as beads for bracelets and necklaces.  You can either do the five true platonic solids, or you can do the six common polyhedral dice used in roleplaying games -- it's up to you which way to go!  (The dice approach, at least, lets you use the six rainbow colors... unless you're a big fan of indigo.)

After printing these, string them onto memory wire and bend the ends of the wire into a curl to make bracelets like I show. Or string them any other way you like onto anything else you like.  
If you print one, please post an I Made One photo.

author: Facocero

description.text:
WIP. Parts have gone through a few revisions now and tested with wires, but changes are still happening.

I'm modifying my Shapeoko 2 with a first run X-Carve upgrade kit from 2015. So, it's missing holes here and there. I also don't have the wiring/drag chain kit the older or newer X-Carve's come with. So, I'm rolling my own wire management and stuff. And while I could let my drill press peck at the plates to make hard mount points, CAD sounded like more fun to while away the hours.

Designed so everything can print flat and help minimize supports everything would need.

The extrusion brackets perform the following tasks:
Hold a 2020 extrusion to the gantry by way of the Makerslide rail. The 2020 is/should be tapped for M5 threading.
Act as bump stops so the extruded carriage doesn't slam into the smooth belt guide wheels.
Act as adjustable bump stops for mech limit switches on the X axis.

The major differences between v1 and v2 is that v2 for sure needs supports due to providing clearance for the drag chain to easily pierce the plane of the gantry side plates.

I will eventually make something so I can use Hall effect endstops. Baby steps.

The drag chain guides and anchor are not necessary, but I like a belts and suspenders approach. They will help ensure that the drag chain more or less stays in place. It's not uncommon for drag chain to have a U channel to lie in. This is my answer to that.

The gantry anchor is definitely wonky, but it'll do the job.

Hardware:
Gantry brackets
x4 M5 x 10mm machine screw
x4 M5 washer
x2 M5 T-slot nuts (Misumi HFS5 style)
x2 M3 x 16mm machine screw
x2 M3 washer
x2 M3 nylock nut

Rail guides and rail drag chain anchor
x7 M5 x 12mm machine screw
x8 M5 T-slot nuts (Misumi HFS5 style)
x1 M5 x 10mm machine screw
x8 M5 washer

Gantry drag chain anchor
x2 M5 x 16mm machine screw
x2 M5 washer
x2 M5 nylock nut
x2 M4 x 10mm machine screw
x2 M4 washer

Drag chain
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LZLU6AN/
R38 18mm x 37mm (flap open close type)

Connectors on the gantry are Molex Microfit 3.0 dual row panel fit plugs.
https://goo.gl/KXrQT
https://www.inventables.com/technologies/molex-microfit-connector-ultimate-kit

I'm also using 5 pin aircraft-ish connectors off of ali-express.
https://www.inventables.com/technologies/panel-connector

description.text:
This "lift kit" was designed to be used with 25mm M-F M3 standoffs. This is where I got mine (These were also nice since they came with nuts so I was able to lock the threads in the machine itself): http://www.ebay.com/itm/322121559859?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=511043842658&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

This was also designed with the intent of having a Raspberry Pi inside the machine with the main board flipped around 180* to completely enclose the USB cable.

Most of these pieces are not printable on the MPSM. For the front and back, I've uploaded two-piece versions that are printable on the MPSM, however the full piece versions, as well as the side panels shown in the pictures were done on my terrible Maker Select V2.

The rear panel allows my cable chain mod to be installed without drilling any holes into the cabinet. However, unlike the original drill version, you will need longer wires for this, especially if your board is flipped. I've uploaded the files for 3 different positions as my original upload was remixed to put the chain in the middle of the bed, I thought I'd be a little more accommodating.

You'll also need to do some soldering to get the power switch to the front, as the positive wire off the barrel plug is not long enough.

The gantry brace for the right side doesn't appear to be lined up perfectly as I am apparently actually terrible at this. I uploaded an offset bracket for the bearing holder that attaches to the X-axis, and it's working fine on my unit. I've also uploaded just a vented right side panel if you're not doing the brace.

PLEASE NOTE While I was printing the second set for my V2, I noticed that some issues with the screw holes on the gantry brace panel that I thought were fixed were still present.

Panel_Right_Brace_Repaired.stl now uploaded.

The left side panel has two keystone jacks for whatever you want. I'm just using the one for an ethernet jack to go to the Pi right now. Just wanted the second there for down the road. I've also relocated the 60mm fan mount to allow you to put the fan inside the cabinet. I'm not very creative, so I put a generic fan guard on (not shown in the pictures).

If you feel you can't find the files for something pictured, please check the "Remixed from" section. I do not upload files that I didn't create or edit. If you still can't find it, ask and I'll see if I can find it.

I'm heavily encouraging remixing the hell out of this to see what else you put on the front / back.

YES, everything should work on the V2. I'm currently waiting on the standoffs for my V2 for this kit.

In case you're wondering about my awesome spool holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/Geonovast/collections/mp-spool-holder

If you're using the gantry support rod, consider this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393720

title: 20mm Test Cube with Upcycle potential - a cube based snap toy.

description.text:
I made a 20mm test cube nearly a year ago for personal use, and since then I have tweaked it by cutting circle and square holes through it to give me the following tests in one:

  1. XYZ calibration - 20mm on each side
  2. Hair test - the holes provide a good hair test.
  3. Bridge Test - if the Square is oriented to the X or Y axis (as opposed to being Z axis oriented).

I ended up with a bunch of test cubes lying around and my kids would play with them, so I decided to create a little connector doo-hickey so that we can make interesting cubic shapes and art with these.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the cube:
Print as needed for your test.

For the Connectors:

  • Printing them upright (Z oriented with the hole facing UP/DOWN) will get you a good looking print that is easy to crack along the Z axis. As far as I know this is a fact of life in Additive 3D printing.

  • Printing them sideways (oriented with the hole in the X or Y direction) will get you a stronger print, but it may not look as sharp.

title: Wooden Barrel Model Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Wooden Barrel Model Kit I submitted for the Envision the Future Design Challenge.

This tactile model is a representation of a small wooden barrel approximately 6 by 4.5 inches to help a visually impaired person understand the traditional craft of making barrels, buckets, baths and all forms of storage containers knows as Coopering. The craftsman who makes them is called a cooper.

A barrel, cask, or tun is a hollow cylindrical container, traditionally made of wooden staves bound by wooden or metal hoops and possessing flat ends or heads.

The model was designed in Autodesk® Fusion 360™ and has been adapted in order to support 3D printing. The model is comprise of 16 staves, 2 chime hoops, 2 bilge hoops and 2 sets of heads (3 parts each) so it can be assemble as either a bank or a jar. All the parts are inscribed with braille for easy identification except for the Top Head Ring used for the jar assembly as this part’s surface does not allow for an inscription and the optional storage box.

Due to the variances in tolerance with different 3D Printers, it may not be possible to take the model apart once the hoops have been fully seated in their respective positions. If the model is to be assemble and disassemble repeatedly, then either the x and y scale of the hoops need to be adjusted during the slicing prior to printing or rubber bands can be used instead of the hoops to keep the model firmly assembled.

All the parts can be printed without support except the Bottom Head Plug in order to allow the braille inscription. The chime and bilge hoops can be printed together as the chime hoop fits inside the bilge hoop with enough clearance. The staves are to be printed on their side. All the STLs have the correct orientation and are centred on the bed for printing. A separate set of STLs without braille are also supplied for people who would like to print the model but do not require the inscriptions.

Common parts to be printed:

16 Staves

2 Chime Hoops

2 Bilge Hoops

For the Bank assembly:

1 Top Head with coin slot

1 Bottom Head with treaded hole

1 Bottom Head Plug treaded

For the Jar assembly:

1 Top Head Ring

1 Top Head Lid

1 Bottom Head Full

Optional:

1 Kit Storage Box

1 Kit Storage Box Lid

Assembly

First, select the appropriate set of heads to assemble the kit as either the bank or the jar.

If assembling the bank you will need the top head with coin slot, bottom head with treaded hole and bottom head plug.

If assembling the jar you will need the top head ring, top head lid and bottom head full.

Next, take one stave in one hand and position it with the outside curve against the palm. Insert both heads it their respective slots at the end of the stave. If assembling the jar, the head ring need to be positioned so the recess it facing out to allow the lid to fit properly.

Continue adding stave one by one making sure they are sitting flush with the previous one and apply pressure on the heads so they do not fall off. Once enough staves are in place the heads will stay put.

Once all the staves are in place its time to secure everything by installing the hoops. The Chime hoops go nearest to the head and the bilge hoops go nearest the middle of the barrel. They fit in grooves so the model stays securely assemble. This will fit very tightly and it may not be possible to remove them once they are fully seated. If you wish to be able to disassemble the model, you may asked the person who printed the kit to adjust the dimension of the hoops so they are loose fitting or you can use rubber bands to temporarily secure the model.

The hoops are tapered to match the outside curve of the staves. Make sure the smaller side is toward the end of the barrel. The smaller side will be up when the inscription is right side up and you can just slip the hoops into the barrel. The chime hoops should be installed first. Use your finger tips to bring them down into their respective grooves. Some force maybe required depending on the fit.

Do the same with the bilge hoops.

The last step remaining is to screw in the bottom plug if you opted for the bank or the lid if you opted for the jar.

Enjoy.

title: Extended Spool Holder With Bearings, Frictionless
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was looking for something with less friction than normal spool mounts, stay pretty universal across different sized rolls, multiple mounting options, easy to print with no supports. Couldn't find what I had in mind, so I made this!

This is a direct replacement for the Monoprice Maker Select (as well as all the clones) so you can use the wider Monoprice spools. Because of the simplicity, other mounts can easily be made for this spool. After I moved my printers to some bakers racks I easily ran some coat hangers.

This should help with some print quality issues some may have. As the printer is printing along the X axis it will pull on the filament. If the filament it tight it will actually lift up on the print head while its printing (not good). When the spool is mounted right above the printer as shown. As I load the filament, I make a loop and then feed it into the printer. This creates a natural spring from the memory curve in the roll. Now as the print head is printing along the X axis the filament can easily be stretched which no longer lifts up on the print head. Also as the filament is being used up, the spring of the filament forces it to unroll to maintain the "spring".

Ill work on uploading a video. But until i can get a timelapse set up, i included a pic of a finished 28hr print. 2 in a row with zero issues from the frictionless spool holder.

Parts required

5/16" x 5" Bolt
1 x 5/16" Nylock nuts
2 x 608 Bearings (8x22x7mm)
Glue
(Nuts and bolt can be substituted for metric 8mm equivalents)

Simple instructions:

  1. Push a bearing into both ends of the spool holder.
  2. Apply some glue and press on the other flanged end.
  3. Assemble as shows. The spacer goes between the red/green pieces, don't over tighten the nut.
  4. Remove your old spool holder and install your new one!

Printer:

Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

For the most part you can print in the settings your are comfortable with. 0.8mm walls gives good room for consistent infill.
Tell us more...

description.text:
This is my take on the Proton Pistol as wielded by Winston Zeddemore and Agent Ortiz in IDW's Ghostbusters comics.

See the thread on GBFans for a full build up, electronics layout, and all that.

Included here are the STL's, core sketchup file with all the drawings, ATTiny85 arduino sketch, and WT588D prop sound chip programmer project file for the pistol. Giving it all away for free!

Print as imported.

Update 10/10/2017: Been meaning to upload this for a while - I've successfully printed entire shell halves with ZERO supports in PLA so long as you've got good cooling. You end up with some open weave inside the gun (in the electronics pocket) but it really affects nothing. The one problem I ran into was that the trigger switch mount and spring mount on the right half won't print correctly without supports, so I used Meshmixer to build in supports to the STL. It prints great, and you just clip the supports off. Very easy. Please leave a comment & picture if you use this version! I've printed about half a dozen now this way.

I also uploaded the .mix file, if you want to tinker with it.

title: KingKong 90GT RX/VTX/Camera Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Angled camera mount for KingKong 90GT. Replaces stock VTX mount plate that camera is glued to. 4 camera angles provided, 15deg, 20deg, 25deg and 30deg. Top plate is wide enough to mount the VTX and FrSky RX side by side. You can still access the buttons on the VTX and RX for changing channel and binding as needed using a thin allen wrench or tool. Hole in top plate to pass the RX Antenna through for strain relief, and rear mount for zip-tie to keep VTX antenna out of the props. Overall adds about 1.5-2g to the Quad and protects the camera, VTX and RX much better along with increased viewing angle making it easier to fly FPV at speed.

Prepare to install:

  • You will need to de-solder the VTX from the ESC board so you can remove the stock CF plate. You can re-solder it back on once removed as the new mount does not require it passing through any holes etc.
  • If your camera hasn't already come loose from crashes, you'll need to break the CA glue holding it onto the VTX plate as well as the base frame. There is a small piece of CF spacer under the camera, you will no longer need that either.

Items you'll need:

  • 3x8mm (or 3x10mm) nylon screws. These are a bit longer than the stock ones.
  • Small Zip-tie for VTX antenna
  • Double sided tape for sticking the VTX and RX (if desired) to top plate. Mount them so the buttons face down.

You may need to file the sides or the lens hole in the mount for your camera to fit properly depending on your printer's tune. On my printer it fits perfectly without adjustment. The fit of the camera is tight as its a friction fit. If yours is loose, you may need to put a drop of CA or hot-glue to secure it in the socket.

Installation:

  • Test fit the notch under the camera mount to the bottom plate of your KK 90GT. Its a friction fit, should be tight, but not impossible to get on. File/sand as needed.
  • Test fit and file as needed the mount to fit your camera. Press camera into the mount, it should go in and be recessed about 1.5-2mm from the end of the mount to protect the lens. Pay attention to orientation, the wires should be at the bottom of the camera, otherwise you might be flipped 180deg.
  • Stick your VTX and RX onto the top plate with buttons facing down. Orientate them so your VTX Antenna is closest to center in the back, and RX antenna can go through the small hole behind the camera.
  • Install a Zip-Tie in the rear hole, there are small notches for it to lock into so it doesn't slide sideways on you. Trim as needed to fit the antenna.
  • Slide the mount onto the front of the frame, the 4 standoffs should line up with the top plate's 4 posts.
  • Install and tighten the 4 new screws and you're done!

Screws - https://www.banggood.com/20pcs-M3-Black-Round-Pillips-Pan-Head-Plastic-Nylon-Screw-Bolt-5681012152025mm-Length-p-1002976.html

FrSky RX - https://us.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-Eachine-Tiny-QX90-Quadcopter-Parts-Frsky-8CH-PPM-SBUS-Receiver-Compatible-Frsky-X9D-PLUS-X9E-DJT-DFT-wp-Usa-1079410.html

I created this as a way to relocate the Nema 17 Motor that runs the extruder to the top of the Monoprice Select Mini V1 in order to gain more space inside for a larger and longer Z axis Lead Screw. I have't Ordered the longer lead screw yet, that's next month's project. but if my calculations are correct, i should be able to get another 20mm of Z.

Ok now for the nitty gritty. I printed this using eSun PLA+. 205/55. The original wire harness that connected the extruder inside of the machine will reach the new location. no modifications are needed. Just make sure the Motors connector for the wiring harness is pointing down towards the hole so you can slip the harness through and reconnect it.

Anyways. i Hope this is of some use to someone working on modifying their printer.

title: XO Bed Leveling Assist
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this bed leveling guide in response to the one I have been using for while now which was just squares inside of squares. Overall, it worked OK, but if you were adjusting the bed height on the fly like I do, you end up making adjustments while the nozzle is moving away from you, and this makes it hard to judge your changes until it comes all the way around.

With the small circles in the corners, you can see very quickly how any adjustments take, and then have a few extra passes just to make sure. The centered X also points right to the likely location of the middle of your next print, just to make sure that everything is good to go.

This is designed with my Wanhao (Maker Select) i3 in mind, so the overall dimensions are about 190mm square.

author: derailed

description.text:
A set of clips and stand offs for fitting a 120mm fan to a reprappro Huxley.
I had a bunch of these 120mm fans kicking around and hooked one up to the spare mosfet on the Sanguinololu controller to try and improve the quality of my prints when printing small parts and bridges. The fan seems to work a treat with PLA on the Huxley and is automatically controlled by slic3r so I decided to make it a permanent fixture.

Update: Added blender source file and added a new stl as the ojects in the original weren't all aligned in z correctly. The main stl has a full set of parts so print that and you should have: 4 x M6 clips
2 x 50mm stand offs
2 x 35mm stand offs
 You will also need: 1 x 120mm 12v fan
8 x M3 x 12mm machine screws
4 x M3 x 20mm machine screws
12 x M3 nuts Find the short edge of all the stand offs. These are the ends that connect to the fan. Fit 12mm screws through from the back and into the fan mounting holes and secure with M3 nuts. Fit the two 35mm stand offs at the top of your fan and the 50mm ones at the bottom. This should angle the fan to point at the print head. Fit 12mm screws to the tabs on the clips. Make sure they go in from the outside of the tab. Fit the longer edge of the stand offs to the screws on the tabs and secure with M3 nuts. Now fit the fan with clips attached to the Huxley frame and secure with 20mm M3 screws and nuts if you feel the need (it is pretty secure without them). Powering the fan: If you have an emaker Reprappro Huxley with a switched heatbed and a Sanguinololu then you will have a spare mosfet channel that you can use to switch the fan on and off from software. The following applies if you are running Sprinter firmware (I haven't looked at alternatives yet). You will need to modify the section of pins.h that corresponds to your motherboard, mine is type "62" (Sanguinololu V1.2 and later ). Look for the line that says "#define FAN_PIN" and set it to "12" (the pin that switches the spare mosfet). Compile and upload and you should be able to switch the fan on and off with M106 and M107.

description.text:
This is a parametric box designed for storing stacks of round or near-round things like board game tokens or coins. You could use it to store lots of other things, too. Dice, candy, gifts, pens, pencils, crayons, super balls, popcorn, marbles, cables, Arduinos, and more.

The container has an outer sleeve and an inner sliding tray. The sleeve has a nib that clicks into a recess in the bottom of the tray so the box snaps shut. There's a viewing window in one side, meant to let you peek at whatever's inside. There's an optional pull ring that can be enabled on the tray to make it easier to open or to attach a lanyard or hang on a hook. You can set the number of sides; it defaults to a hex box (6 sides), but any increment of 4 after that will work (10, 14, 18...).

The model was designed with OpenSCAD. Use it with Customizer or download the SCAD file and edit it in OpenSCAD. The premade STL files provide an example tube that holds $10 in US quarters, with and without a pull ring.

The photos show a couple of tubes I printed to hold board game tokens.

This script and design are licensed under an Attribution-NonCommercial license. As always, if you'd like a different license, get in touch with me here or on Twitter.

Please leave comments! Or upload your own prints with the "I Made One" button. I'd love to see how you're using it!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You may need to adjust the tolerance variables to suit your printer.

I recommend using 2 or 3 shells; the parts will end up being nearly solid. Printing is pretty straightforward. It's designed to print the 6-sided box without supports, though if you increase the number of sides, the slopes of the tray sides may need supports.

I recommend printing the tray and sleeve one at a time. In Cura 14 and 15 (not 2.x), you can right-click the two-piece combo and select "Split object into parts". I think Simplify 3D has a similar feature. Or you can use toggles in Customizer or the OpenSCAD file to export one object at a time.

Any material should work. The containers in the photos are printed in PETT (t-glase).

The first time you assemble the container, the tray may be a hard fit into the sleeve. Just work it back and forth a bunch of times until it gets easier to use. If you need to, you could reach inside the sleeve with a file or a knife and take a little material off the locking nib. You could also carve away some of the leading edge of the tray so it gets over the bump more easily.

I needed a container for carting around about 50 custom tokens for Imperial Assault. Sure, there are lots of containers on Thingiverse, but nothing looked quite right.

I started by modifying Parametric Coin Storage Tubes to use a hinged cap instead of a free-floating piece. It worked okay, but tokens easily turned sideways when getting them in or out of the tubes.

Next, I looked at The HIVE - Stackable Hex Drawers, but the design isn't parametric and I didn't need the stackable features.

The final design is inspired by The HIVE, but is easily customized for whatever you need to store. You can size it by the size and number of tokens you have or by overall internal length. It has an optional pull ring to make it easier to open, to add a lanyard, or to hang it on a hook. It has a window so you can see what's inside and how full it is. It has a latch so you can snap it closed pretty securely. The removable drawer makes it easier to fill and empty the container. It's a great way to organize coins and game pieces.

comments.text: Any tips or suggestions on the best settings for the release latch? I print the tray so it fits snuggly and still slides inside the sleeve. But the latch bump will hold the tray so tightly that I can't make it release without trimming some plastic manually.

Notes:

Stop the print at .5 mm and change color.
Stop again at 1 mm and change the color back to original color or whatever color you want.

Needs to be printed using a flexible filament.

Took 2 hr 20 min on my Folger Tech FT-5.

2 top layers and 2 bottom layers with 2 perimeter walls

50 mm per sec using Cura

comments.text: Hey there. Good idea. I have been working out a technique for signs that I think may help you. The idea is to print on glass (or smooth surface) and the multi-color layer is applied first at 0.1mm height, and adjust the printer to over-extrude. Then print the rest of the part starting at 0.3mm height. The background (black in this case) will fill in all areas around the first layer and "embed" the first layer into the part. And if you are printing on a glass bed, the end result is smooth and shinny. Need to keep the bed temperature constant between print jobs so that the prior printed parts do not detach. BTW, the first layer print needs to be mirrored.

title: Top Load Filament Spool Brackets - 2020 T-Slot Aluminum

description.text:
I know there are a lot of Top Loading Spool Holders similar to this set, but I couldn't find a set that worked exactly like I wanted it to, so I designed these. I designed them not to need any screws or other hardware, other than the cross bar (7mm threaded rod) that came with the printer.

It's designed to have the center of gravity off center, so that it will "lean" forward, holding it in place and without too much lean, so that it won't put too much pressure on the backside hook. You can use it either in a forward or reverse configuration.

Notes:
After printing my brackets, I made a couple of minor changes I decided they needed; One is cosmetic and the others are functional. To make a better connection between the arms and the mounts, I filleted the connection to give it a sloped curve. Also, I increased the thickness to give them more strength. For my print the arms have a thickness of 5mm and are functioning, but I increased their thickness to 10mm. they felt like they needed it. If you think it's over-kill or you want to save plastic/time you can decrease their thickness.

Also, for staying mounted purposes, I designed them to be tight fitting. Some filing to clean up the print and open the mounts to fit the 2020 t-Slot Extruded Aluminum may be necessary.

title: 360-12 Power supply cover for Tronxy P802

description.text:
After printing this Power Supply mount:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2258041
Tronxy P802 Mounting Bracket for MeanWell LRS-350-12 Power Supply

I needed a cover that would add a power cord socket as well as a power switch. Everyone else seems to be using a socket/swich combo which extends the power cord out of the side of the printer. I prefer the cord to be in back so I designed this around parts that i already had on hand. I used a Radio Shack P/N 275-692 illuminated switch, but any switch that will fit a 3/4" hole will work. Just search on Amazon. The power cord socket is out of an ATX computer power supply & is readily available online.
https://www.amazon.com/Panel-Power-Inlet-Sockets-Connectors/dp/B00843KZP0/ref=pd_sim_23_9?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B00843KZP0&pd_rd_r=2P3NV60J7KFCVXFBACG4&pd_rd_w=qIWUN&pd_rd_wg=6c5S9&psc=1&refRID=2P3NV60J7KFCVXFBACG4

https://www.radioshack.com/collections/switches/products/spst-neon-rocker-switch
This was done in Sketchup, so it can be altered to suit your own needs.
This needs to be printed switch side down. I used some old black crummy PLA which is perfect for something like this. A good place to use up some less-than-desirable filament.

Installation notes:

The power cord socket is attached with either 3 mm screws/nuts or 6-32 screws/nuts.
All connections to the power cord socket & switch are made with crimp on insulated spade connectors. The cover is attached using 4 mm screws into the existing threaded holes in the
power supply.

print_settings.Notes:: See the Bill Of Material (BOM) for the various hardware needed in addition to the printed parts.

description.text:
This is a major modification / upgrade for the CR-10 S4. A few things you need to know right away:

1) If you don't feel comfortable taking your printer apart and putting it back together, and troubleshooting any issues you might introduce, this is not a modification you should attempt.

2) Some of my design decisions, particularly around the tensioner, were driven by the parts available to me. There's no doubt that there are better, more elegant solutions for that part.

3) This modification is targeted for the S4 however there is no reason it could not be applied to the standard 300x300mm CR-10. In that case the belt would need to be shortened and the angle of the support brackets adjusted.

https://youtu.be/mVY5oR_-VKs

That being said this modification introduces added Z stability for the gantry. The lead screws are identical so that a full turn of either screw results in the same Z travel. The screws both have an identical belt gear on them so that Xmm of belt travel results in the same amount of rotation on both screw. The belt is kept under tension so there is no opportunity for it to slip from either gear. Both screws move in unison and so the level of the gantry is maintained throughout the whole Z axis

Additionally the diagonal bracing adds stability to the gantry towers. When printing small infill or other zigzag patterns the back and forth motion of the print bed can induce a vibration of the gantry towers and the gantry (and print head). This is more noticeable the higher the gantry goes, on tall prints. The diagonal bracing prevents that vibration, increasing the potential for quality prints under conditions that would otherwise affect that quality.

Top spool holder arms, from another of my designs, have been added here for convenience. This way to hold the spool makes a lot of sense in the context of this modification.

Front side view

Rear side view

Having questions about this mod? Want to discuss and share your ideas for improvements? Come to this thread on the CR Forum and I'll be happy to answer!

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 to 0.32 mm

Infill:

25%-40%

Notes:

I recommend top and bottom layers at 1.2mm and walls at 1.2mm. This adds rigidity and and gives a bit of meat around the holes in case your printer tolerances are a bit off and you need to drill them out.

I printed some parts in PETG and some in PLA and both materials work well.

See the Bill Of Material (BOM) for the various hardware needed in addition to the printed parts.

Assembly

1) Remove the top bar of the gantry towers. Remove the lead screw support bracket from the top bar.

2) Support the gantry with something and undo the brass lead screw nut from the gantry. There are four small lock washers with the two bolts holding that brass lead screw nut, be careful you don't lose them. Loosen the bolt on the flexible coupler between the screw and Z stepper motor to allow the removal and free movement of the lead screw.

3) Move the gantry up and past the towers to completely free it from the printer. You may need to disconnect wires.

4) Install a pillow block onto the idler base.

5) Remove plate that holds the 3 bolts and wheels on the right end of the gantry by removing two bolts.

6) Undo the three bolts holding the wheels and replace them with m5 50mm bolts. Put the stock spaces and wheels back on then add the 3 9mm spaces along with a couple of M5 washers on each bolt. Add the gantry plate onto the 3 bolts and secure with the stock nuts. Gantry Plate Installed

7) Install the gantry back by sliding it back down onto the towers (have something to support it so it doesn't slide all the way down).

8) Install the tensioner onto the top bar of the gantry tower and secure the top bar back onto the towers. Make sure the tensioner extends towards the back of the printer. Tensioner

9) Install the left and right caps onto the gantry towers with the longer ends facing the front.
Caps on top of the gantry towers

10) Thread the GT2 belt in the tensioner and to both caps.

11) This is the hard part. Thread the new lead screw through the gantry plate. Add a GT2 pulley near the top of the screw ( gears nearest the top) and the new brass lead screw nut near the bottom. Slide the lead screw up into the cap making sure that the end loop of the belt is captured by the lead screw. Install the idler base and slide the bottom of the lead screw into the pillow block. Secure the lead screw to the pillow block with the grub screws.
Idler Base

12) Install a pillow block facing down into the hole of the cap with the lead screw, making sure to capture the top of the lead screw into the pillow block. Secure the lead screw to the pillow block with the grub screws.
Pillow Block on top of lead screw

13) Slide the GT2 gear up until it nearly touches the pillow block and secure to the lead screw with the grub screws. Place the end of the belt into the flanges of the GT2 gear.

14) On the original lead screw add a GT2 pulley near the top of the screw ( gears nearest the top), undo the screws securing the Z stepper motor to the frame and slide the stepper motor out of the way. Slide the lead screw up into the cap making sure that the end loop of the belt is captured by the lead screw. Install the stepper motor back onto the frame and slide the bottom of the lead screw into the flexible coupler. Secure the lead screw to the flexible coupler.

15) Install a pillow block facing down into the hole of the cap with the lead screw, making sure to capture the top of the lead screw into the pillow block. Secure the lead screw to the pillow block with the grub screws.

16) Slide the GT2 gear up until it nearly touches the pillow block and secure to the lead screw with the grub screws. Place the end of the belt into the flanges of the GT2 gear.

17) Rotate the original brass lead screw nut until it is aligned with its mounting plate and secure it back in place using the two original bolts and four washers. Two of those washers sit between the brass nut and the mounting plate so you need to be creative to reassemble. Fine tweezers are a good way to put that blind washer in the right spot. You can now remover whatever you were using to support the gantry.

18) Assemble the tensioner. Cut a 130mm length of M5 threaded rod and screw a M5 nylock nut at one end. Insert the rod into the tension idler so the nut sits inside the hex hole. Place the tension idler into the tensioner and guide the end of the rod out the hole at the end of the tensioner. Screw on the knob and M5 bolt onto the rod and cap the rod with a M5 acord nut. With the idler pulley capture the near part of the belt and install the idler pulley into the tension idler with a M5 30mm bolt and M5 nut. Use a M5 bolt and nut to secure the second idler pulley and the M8 nut and bolt to secure the 608ZZ bearing.
Tensioner top
Tensioner belt under tension
Tensioner assembled
Tensioner from below
Tensioner view of bearing

19) Tension the belt by turning the knob on the tensioner. Make sure the belt is well seated within the flanges of the GT2 gears and the idler pulley. Get the belt nice and tight with no slack.

20) With a level (I used a spirit level) ensure that the frame is level along the X axis. With the frame level ensure that the gantry is also level You may need to readjust the eccentric nut on the inside wheel on the right gantry tower.

21) With both the frame and gantry level install the new brass lead screw nut into the gantry plate with M3 screws. If you need to turn the lead screw to get proper alignment loosen the grub screws on the GT2 gear on that lead screw so you can turn the screw without turning the belt. With the lead screw nut installed, ensure all grub screws are tight on the pillow blocks and GT2 gear.

22) Install the four support brackets on all four corners of the frame. One of the t-nuts needs to be pre-placed between the heads of the two existing bolts. Make sure that the hole at the top of the bracket is facing towards the gantry towers.
Assembled Bracket with threaded rod

23) Measure and cut the four M6 threaded rods to size (60cm rear and 61.5cm front) and install, connecting the corner brackets to the caps. Starting at the bottom the assembly along the rod should be M6 acorn nut, washer, bracket, M6 nut, M6 nut, cap, washer, M6 nut. Tighten the nuts at the cap to remover the slack from the threaded rod but you don't need a ton of tension in the threaded rods. Make sure you don't pull the gantry tower crooked when doing this.
Assembled cap with threaded rod

The knob on the tensioner is not my design but everything else is. The knob design is from idig3d (https://www.thingiverse.com/idig3d) as seen in his work here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2020468

description.text:
I had previously printed braces and there was some wobble to the entire printer when trying to install them. Turned out my printer/bed might not have been totally level. So I set out to design a brace tat allowed the printer to sit directly on the bed, thus reducing the effects of an uneven bed or printer.

Got inspiration from a few other designs and remixed it into what I wanted...

Using tomfrajer's oldham coupler setup, included here for your convenience.

Of course, nothing beats a well calibrated printer

title: Star Wars Funko Vinyl POP! Stand

description.text:
I collect the Star Wars Funko Vinyl POPs and one (1) I've collected did not come with a stand, so I designed one to be similar to the stands that come with all the other Star Wars Pops. It can be used to put a stand under any that does not come with one already or to replace a lost or broken one.

Of course the pegs are positioned and sized differently for each Pop! This one, as-is, is designed to match the feet of the Storm Trooper that came in the Dewback set. It can be used as-is with many other Star Wars Pops or modified to fit any of them.

Notes:
1.) You have to paint the Star Wars logo text on the front, unless you can make a decal to place on there.
2.) If your making this for the Dewback Storm Trooper, you will have to decide how you want to use the stand with it; if you're a die-hard collector, you may not want to drill holes in the feet because it might ruin it's collectable value or it may not. It may make it more valuable to have a stand. You have to decide, but there are other options: instead of drilling holes, you can print the stand without the posts and use double-sided tape or some other temporary or permanent adhesive. You can modify the design of the stand to have straps to put the feet under or recesses where the Troopers feet snap in. There are many options.

comments.text: Is there a good way to measure the feet holes for my funko pop?
comments.author: alexrfan03

comments.text: I use calipers to measure the distance between the holes and the size the pegs should be by measure the size of the holes on the bottom of their feet.  If there are no holes on the bottom of their feet, you can drill holes (only a 1/4" deep) in their heels, but if you drill you might ruin their collectable value, but it could be the value goes up, because now it will have a stand.
comments.author: alexrfan03

comments.text:
The foot pegs are a little large, otherwise the model is good.
Easily fixed with a small file.

title: MP Select Mini V2 Z Axis

description.text:
This I made for my new MP Select Mini V2. Possible just my luck but the new V2 mini seemed to have a longer X-axis arm which made the old clap system not work. It was off by about 4mm so I made this new clap. It worked great. I revised it a bit after using it for a while and added the counter sunk holes inside the bearing mount. I used screws identical to the bed screws on the MP Select Mini but any small taped head should work fine- you will need to use new screw (longer) to secure the bearing clap to the x-axis bar. I left the bar on my Mini since I think the extra support is needed.

Product Links:
M3 Screws: http://amzn.to/2q7PdFK
3M Glass Bed Tape: http://amzn.to/2qMBntD
Vibration Pads: http://amzn.to/2r7oGg9 (come in 2x2 and 4x4 work well)
PLA PRO- http://amzn.to/2q7UvkQ (great material in my opinion)
Bed Wires: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W1MqNMbGtDY (not my video)
Glass Bed- http://amzn.to/2rs14CN (or goto Lowes and get the to cut you one 2$)
MP WIKI- http://mpselectmini.com/mods

Bed Wire Option:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2302588
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179761 (move fan use fan holes)

  1. Drill new hole like the video
    Silicone WIre: http://amzn.to/2q7zG8Z

Things I learned about the V2- (fair and not so fair)

  1. The control button has much better control and works decently now!
  2. It still has issues :( the bed is the same, they added some cheap cotton blanket to the bottom that is barley taped in place. So you might to fix that before you ever start printing.
  3. The bed I received was warped. High in the middle- I added a glass bed so that actually fixed the issue of the warped aluminum. I used 3M adhesive tape for the glass bed and it worked outstandingly well. Just cut the glass to leave your bed leveling screws access for removal and leveling.
  4. The hot end is better- its a cheap E3D clone and performs as such. Not great but should be better in the long run.
  5. This machine was louder than the last one. I even printed some Z-Axis stabilizers for the inside tower and it still did not quit rattling.
  6. The bed wires are still an issue. My original mini cut the heated bed wires since they rub against the mounting blocks and pulley. I recommend rerouting them as the link shows below.
  7. It printed fine for 3 days and then the bed thrmoresistor went out causing the bed to quit heating, this was after it was about 120 degrees Celsius and I thought it might burn it self up! lol
  8. The X-axis pulley on the right side used to be metal, however the new one is plastic for some ungodly reason. After a few days printing this pulley and gear fell apart almost and shelled plastic pieces all over the X-axis arm. Terrible design change in my opinion.
  9. When it prints the prints are pretty decent for a 220$ machine. With some mods and tweaking I think its still almost worth the 220$ if you want to tinker with it.
  10. Cooling fan seems to be much quieter which is great, the cooling shroud however I am not to sure on how well it will cool the parts. Its an odd design in my opinion and leaves little air flow left for part cooling.

Unfortunately I had to RMA this unit, due to all the issues above- I have not had the best of luck with these cheap machines and hopefully the new replacement will fair better.

Printer:

MP Select Mini V2

Resolution:

.20 to .15

Infill:

75 Triangular

Notes:

Print with the parts standing up, seems to work just fine like that on my end. No supports needed. Holes are all 3mm with threads on the cap screws.

author: Pelphry17

description.text:
Our kitten is a year old now, and not a kitten anymore! I originally designed the Small Pet Door Wall Frame so our cat could go from the house to the garage, where his litter box is located. Now he is too big for that little door, so I redesigned the frame for the medium Ideal Pets pet door, with a 7" x 11.5" opening.

The Ideal Pet door is a quality product with a vinyl flap and lock-out slide, and runs about $22 from many retailers. Out of the box, the door telescopes to 2" and is designed to be installed in a door. This 3D printed frame extends the range to about 6" to 7" so it can be installed in a wall instead.

The frame is printed in two parts so it can be printed on a 200 x 200 mm print bed. One of the dimensions is 204 mm, but most 200 mm beds are actually a little wider (mine is 214 mm), so you may need to increase the dimensions of your print area to > 205 mm before printing the frame. I printed the frame with 0.3 mm layers and 30% infill.

This design also includes six braces to improve the strength of the design. The mounting screws put the frame under tension along its weak axis, which can cause it to split over time. In this design, the tension is transferred to the braces, which are printed such that the tension is applied along the strong axis.

2020 bracket.
i remixed this to allow for both ways to connect the frame parts together.

I got tired of the mess and frustration to install the cylinder over the piston when doing a top end so I made this tool. It's for RM250 64.4mm piston but will probably work for slightly larger and smaller pistons.
I made the prototype out of PLA but I'll most likely make the next one from ABS(The PLA part warped some when I left it in the sun)

Just add a M3 X 20-25 screw and compress the rings with a zip-tie around it all. Then when cylinder is over the rings then just cut the zip-tie.

Send me a message and I can adjust the model for different pistons.

12-20-17 Added 94mm and 96mm models

title: Royal Game of Ur
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Royal Game of Ur, based on the ancient board game on display at the British museum.

There are other versions of this on thingiverse, but I wanted to try and recreate the colored inlay found in the original board. The main board is in two pieces with a dovetail joint, and has 3mm holes to accept the inlaid pieces. Tolerances are tested with a monoprice maker select v2, but should be forgiving. Pieces may be snug enough to press fit but I used glue to it would be more durable. The really small pieces can be a tight fit, I used a spare token to lever some of them in.

For the dice, I just printed them in white and used a sharpie to color 2 of the points.

For a full functional game, you will need to print:
1x board left
1x board right
4x dice
7x tokens (white)
7x tokens (black)
35x inlay circle large (white)
35x inlay circle large (black)
35x inlay circle large (black)
5x inlay circle medium (red)
20x inlay petal (red)
20x inlay petal (blue)
45x inlay circle large (blue)
12x inlay circle medium (blue)
50x inlay circle small (blue)

You can print all the pieces of one color together as a raft. My final model was made with a total of 6 prints. I highly recommend printing a few extra of each inlay piece, as they are very easy to lose during assembly

author: MrGlass

description.text:
This is a Remix of another fan blade design. I tried using the original design at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1822959 but the hole on the coupling was too shallow to stay on my motor, and too small to drill a correctly aligned hole through. Thus, this larger blade was created, with a pre-fabricated hole through its center, eliminating the need for any drilling. However, if drilling is needed, the hole is present to promote the correct alignment of the drill bit. I have included 2 similar STL files, with the only difference between them being the diameter of the axle they will accept.

Dimensions
Overall volume: disc of 100mm x 100mm x 5mm
Outer diameter: 100mm (3.937in)
Outer circle thickness: 1mm (0.039in)
Blade pitch: 30º to the horizontal
Blade thickness: 2mm (0.079in)
Axle diameter: available in 2mm or 3mm (0.079in or 0.118in)

title: Galaxy S8 cupholder wireless charger for 2017 Elantra

description.text: The Elantra relies on "Android Auto" or "Apple Carplay" for its Navigation features among other things. However they don't provide any place to put your phone when your driving. Even worse, most smart phones draw more power from the cars built-in USB port than the port can provide, so the phone battery steadily drains. To exacerbate the situation further, to use "Android Auto" you must plug into the car's buit-in USB. As a workaround, this charger should be able to wirelessly charge the phone while Android Auto uses the USB port. A bit messy but it works.

title: Basic Door Wedge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A very simple doorstop designed because the office ran out of them (don't ask ;))

Designed primarily for use on carpets, though it will probably work on smoother surfaces as well. If it is slipping, wrap a few elastic bands along its length usually provide it enough traction to work again - though I can't guarantee it!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

High density (>50%): Honeycomb or Triangle

Notes:

I advise printing this upside down (with the ridges facing upwards) to ensure that the lamination is at an angle to wedge, which will reduce delamination of the part through use.

You can also print it on it's side to achieve a similar effect - but if doing this then the infill must be solid or have a high compressive strength (like a dense honeycomb or triangle-based fill)

Update July 26: Did some tweaks on XY Axis Mounts and Clamps

Update July 23: New Pictures! I've changed Hotend mount to this one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004928.

Update May 24: I have tagged this thing as WORK IN PROGRESS. Not because the printer is not working in its current state (actually it's working quite awesome!) but because I'm updating a couple of parts to make them more appealing (XY Axis Holder) or more functional (all Endstops)

This is a sub-250 USD Ultimaker Clone.

Total Costs are below 250 USD or 220 EUR, beating the price tag of the popular CL 260 UM-Clone. I've made a couple of design changes - see pictures for reference. And despite it's low price point the printer works exceptionally accurate.

Note: I'm still tweaking a thing or two, so expect changes to printed parts over time.

title: 2:1 Dual Extrusion Y-splitter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update Oct 12 2017
Redesigned the entire thing to add more space between the heater block and mounts.
Fan now has more even air flow.
Parts are more sturdy because of 4 mounting points.
Splitter is now shorter with space to use filament for strain relief.

Print at your own risk.
I can't remember when I designed this if I strayed from the standard Prusa rod spacing...

Now that's out of the way, this is a simple Y-splitter that acts as a mount for your E3Dv6 hot end. Got this working on my Folgertech 2020 i3.
There's a lot of refinement that I want to put into these designs but don't have the time currently.

There is a small problem when the filament switches; doing the quick "push pull" will leave a blob on your print wherever a filament starts/stops. With more experimentation I'm sure this effect could be mitigated.

Use caution when printing, especially at the start. Unloading whatever material at the end of a job will require you to load which ever material is getting printed first, but keeps your filament from jamming in the splitter.

Use some variant of this gcode for your tool changes:

CURA 2.6.0 BETA
I prefer to use Cura as it has prime towers built in but because it's the beta somethings don't always work quite right.

Here is a quick program that I made to work with Cura:
https://github.com/Deepfriedchril/Slic3r-Prime-Tower-Gen

; Extruder Start
G91                       ; Relative moves.
G1 E105 F2000     ; Quickly load next material 95%.
G1 E5 F2000         ; Slowly load last 5%.
G90                       ; Abolute moves.
G92 E0          ; Set extruder position to 0

; Extruder End
G91                       ; Relative moves.
G1 E4 F500           ; Quicky extrude about the length of your melt zone.
G1 E-2 F1000       ; Do a quick retraction a little shorter than your melt zone. This is to avoid stringing.
G4 P2500             ; Wait 2.5 seconds so that filament can set.
G1 E-108 F 8000  ; Quickly pull filament out of the Y-splitter.
G90                       ; Abolute moves.
G92 E0          ; Set extruder position to 0

;End gcode
M104 S0
M140 S0
; Pull out old material
G91              ; Relative moves.
G1 E4 F500       ; Quicky extrude about the length of your melt zone.
G1 E-2 F1000     ; Do a quick retraction a little shorter than your melt zone. This is to avoid stringing.
G4 P2500         ; Wait 2.5 seconds so that filament can set.
G1 E-108 F 8000  ; Quickly pull filament out of the Y-splitter.
G90              ; Abolute moves.
G92 E0           ; Set Extruder position to 0

T0               ; Select extruder 0 so that Octoprint reads the correct temp

G28 X0 Y180
M84

SLIC3R

;Tool change gcode for E3Dv6
G91                     ; Relative moves.
G1 E4 F500          ; Quickly extrude about the length of your melt zone.
G1 E-2 F1000       ; Do a quick retraction a little shorter than your melt zone. This is to avoid stringing.
G4 P2500             ; Wait 2.5 seconds so that filament can set.
G1 E-108 F 8000   ; Quickly pull filament out of the Y-splitter.
G90                     ; Absolute moves.

; Load in next extruder
T[next_extruder]   ;  Select next material.
G91                     ; Relative moves.
G1 E105 F2000     ; Quickly load next material 95%.
G1 E5 F2000         ; Slowly load last 5%.
G90                     ; Absolute moves.

This will require:

  • 2x 35m3 screws (main assembly)
  • 2x 10m3 screws (main assembly)
  • 5x m3 locking nuts or regular(not recommended)
  • 2x 16m3 screws (fan duct)

Since these lamps were quite common and I've seen a lot of broken ones in second-hand shops, I thought I'd share this replacement part. Due to poor design the original part always breaks, since actually the lampshade is hinged only on a 1 mm thin injection-molded plastic tube.
I printed the part in the foto from black ABS to achieve the best match with the original. It also printed very well from PETG, but with my material the color was off. Use 0.1mm layers and 80-100% infill for stability.
I just removed the original custom threaded tube with pliers and screwed them into the replacement part. It bites well without tapping.
I made a version with inbuilt print supports, which worked out much better than using Cura's supports.You have to cut them out carefully to get the little plastic tube nice and smooth on the outside.

This adapter is for Triumph Spitfires, and it allows you to mount a modern single din radio in place of the factory radio. It should fit in every year spitfire as well as a TR7. There is a blank one and one with my company logo I would measure the opening in your own car to make sure they are close to the same then adjust the size in makerprint with scaling.

For this year the last design of one of my own students. She loves, that everything is good organized, so she made a box for her pens. While transferring the skp-file to an stl-file, the model dimensions hadn't been transferred correctly. So, when we printed it first, it was really very small (green picture). So we changed the dimensions with Cura and got a model, which is about 12cm in height (orange picture).

title: Slide Projector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Slide projectors display images with an incredible contrast ratio and allow us to create pictures using simple materials such as paper.
This is projector is as simple as it gets, an LED light source, a convex lens (from a magnifying glass) and a projection lens of eBay.

• Modify the panels to fit the size of your lenses and light source
  • Laser cut the parts
  • Put together and add a dia slide
    • It might be a good idea to test all the components together before cutting the pieces. I used a 100mm projection lens, so any other focal length might result in different distances within the system. The ones used here are: Be careful to use a light source that does not get too hot, I used an LED lamp. However, one should try and find one above 500 lumens and with as less LEDs as possible, as more than one LED results in an unevenly lit projection.

print_settings.Notes:: Right pin

description.text:
I made this to replace a stock sun visor of a Fiat Panda model 169.
It is the right sun visor (passenger seat).

I printed it using PLA for proof-of-concept purposes. However it works pretty well.

The detachable part of the visor was completely broken in the original one so I designed a small part (LeftPin) that fits properly.
The rotating part is designed in two parts: Holder and RightPin. The latter must be mounted on the holder by using a screw that must not be so tight, since the pin must rotate.

The assembly holder and right pin must then be inserted on the visor and then everything must be mounted on the ceiling of the car.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Left pin
print vertically, with support.

Holder
print with the side that you can see once mounted on the bottom, with support.

Right pin
print on the long side, giving some offset on the Z axis and using support, in order to have a better rounded shape.

Depending on the tolerances that you have with the printer and the filament you are using, you have to sand the right pin in order to fit inside the visor properly and allow for smooth movement of the visor, with three steps (closed, half open, full open).

Finally, put some solid grease on the right pin before inserting it into the visor. It will help to smooth the movement and ease the mounting process.

comments.text:
The original design was with a metal bolt, but I wanted to get away from that and make the whole thing 3D printed.
With a % large infill, there is not really any need for a bolt. If you break the peg you'd be trying to clamp the piece way too tight.
comments.author: Nalmo

comments.text: This is not true. My initial design already provides a fully printed version for light duty use only. In my humble opinion, you don't want to print everything because it takes time, it costs and it could not be as efficient. Like in the original design, you get a much stronger cam clamp gluing a 20mm PVC pipe instead of a printed pin. Wood dowels should fit too. It was never intended to be metal.
comments.author: Nalmo

comments.text: Apologies - I was thinking of another design with a central bolt which I remixed. I find the fully printed 3d printed version can apply more than adequate force for my needs. Certainly a bolt item stronger.

title: Configurable Plant Sign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I just created a new version of my configurable plant signs.

  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:894998
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:896377
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:895187

This version now includes all 3 different designs and the option for two lines of text.

Use the configurator to enter text, choose style and specify the size of your sign.
Download and print.

I printed mine with the following settings:

  • PLA
  • 0.2mm layers
  • 210C extrudor
  • 65C heatbed
  • 60C heatbed (layer 5 and above)
  • cooling on

Print the layers for text and border slowly and use cooling to get a nice and clean print.
For a two colored version stop your printer at 3/4 of print height and change your filament.

author: NeoP5

description.text:
Sculpture I made for a work colleague. The sculpture depicts a mother father and child, and two dogs (I aimed for them to look like beagles).

Modelled in Autodesk Meshmixer, finished in Windows 3D builder.

The actual model is quite small, I scaled it up in Simplify 3D for slicing.

Make sure you add in enough supports under the arms. They clean up quite well with a stanley knife afterwards.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.05

Infill:

30%
After snapping off the supports, use a sharp stanley knife / Xacto Blade to clean up any burs or sharp edges by using a controlled shaving motion. Do not sand.
See general summary

I made an awesome functional mini R2-D2 from Star Wars. The R2-D2, pronounced Artoo-Deetoo, is aesthetically similar to the original movie version. In addition, this mini R2-D2 can roll around, beep boop and turn on an LED! The chassis is comprised of five parts that were 3-D printed and painted. An arduino with a motor shield, an mp3 shield and a bluethooh rx/tx board serves as the brains inside of the chassis. The mini R2-D2 is powered by two small battery packs and the two motors are controlled via a bluetooth packet from my cell phone.  
It took me about 50 hours to design the R2D2 in CATIA.

The STL's are scaled to fit my bed size exactly 6"x8"x6". Also, the arms are hollow, so if you use supports then be sure to adjust the spacing so that they are easier to knock out. The 5 parts took about 40 hours to print.

comments.text:
We printed this robot, thanks for sharing the model.
I don't see how to make the head fit without interfering with the internal cylinder of the arm (you may see it on the pic of our made)
I would like to use an encoder on the motor shaft but I am not sure it will fit.
How did you set the mechanism to roll the head?
comments.author: meirm

comments.text: Hi meirm, i ended up cutting a little part of the lip of the head to make it sit flush. Alternatively you can cut into the arm cylindars that attach to the body.  As for your encoders you might not have enough room in the boots of  r2d2. After poking out my infill i barely had enough room to fit my motors and i ended up needing to cut out some extra space.  I designed the model in catia and it  i definately more of a prototype than a 100% perfect robot.

title: JAG: A8 Rear Brace (with screw-down tabs)

description.text:
This thing is a simple variation on the great Frame Brace design by Simhopp.
I have added extra tabs for screws, so you can fix the printer down to a benchtop to increase stability and improve prints.
Changes were made with Tinkercad (as this wasn't a complex mod).

I also have a similar variation on the Front Brace by Simhopp - added screw mounts:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2291581

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10mm Grid

Notes:

I printed my brace with a 0.4 line width and a 2mm wall width, 1mm top and bottom.
Whilst I think the part would be strong enough without infill, some of the upper 'roof' sections need some support, so I used a simple 10mm grid option, rather than an infill percentage.

I do note that the rear hole for cables is sightly mis-aligned with my version of the A8, but still useable. I also had to open-up the front bolt mounting holes with a drill-bit (I suspect my print accuracy is at fault there).
